awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:   Phylogeny and evolutionary exploration of the C3-CAM phenotypic space in Calandrinia (Montiaceae)
awd_abstract_narration:
Crassulacean Acid Metabolism (CAM) photosynthesis is a complex set of traits that improves water use and photosynthetic efficiency in plants under drought and temperature stress.  Calandrinia (Montiaceae) is an ideal lineage in which to investigate the evolutionary assembly of CAM photosynthesis. This research integrates phylogenetics, anatomy, ecology, physiology, greenhouse experiments, and gene expression studies to unravel the incremental assembly of CAM photosynthesis in Calandrinia. In light of ongoing global change and the increasing acidification of the global landscape (~40% of terrestrial Earth is already considered arid, semi-arid or sub-humid), CAM photosynthesis will likely play an important role in the future of carbon sequestration, sustainable biomass production, and food-crop security. With such imminent change ahead, it is more important than ever that we understand the evolutionary underpinnings of CAM photosynthesis, which may guide current efforts to engineer this syndrome into food and biofuel crops.

The researchers will conduct a comparative gene expression study across species that represent C3, CAM, and CAM-intermediate types. They will use a comparative transcriptomic approach to answer the following questions: 1) how does differential gene expression of key CAM genes vary across the potentially intermediate types, 2) which gene copies are being recruited into new CAM function, 3) are there parallel nucleotide/ amino acid changes in gene copies recruited to perform CAM, and 4) how can transcriptome data help us to better differentiate and define these C3-CAM intermediates? Results from this study will yield the first lineage-based model of CAM evolution.

por.por_cntn:
Crassulacean Acid Metabolism (CAM) photosynthesis is a complex syndrome of traits that improves water use and photosynthetic efficiency in plants under drought and temperature stress.  It has evolved from the more typical C3 photosynthetic pathway – the pathway found in most green plants – likely hundreds of times, and is a ubiquitous and important ecological adaptation in drier regions of the world. In addition to full CAM, there are many recognized intermediate photosynthetic types that have been hypothesized to represent evolutionary steps along the C3 - CAM trajectory. However, there has been no thorough phylogenetic analysis of any CAM-evolving plant lineage, so there has been no explicit demonstration of how these potentially intermediate types relate to one another, or to the evolution of a full CAM syndrome. Calandrinia (Montiaceae) is an ideal lineage in which to investigate the evolutionary assembly of CAM photosynthesis, as species within this group are known to span the C3 to CAM phenotypic spectrum. This research integrates phylogenetics, anatomy, ecology, physiology, greenhouse experiments, and gene expression studies to unravel the incremental assembly of CAM photosynthesis in Calandrinia. 

Funds from this proposal specifically supported the comparative gene expression component of this study. To assess differential gene expression (i.e. what genes are being expressed) across the C3 to CAM phenotypic spectrum we collected seeds from representative Calandrinia species growing across Australia. Seeds were then planted and grown to maturity at the Brown University greenhouse for subsequent physiological and molecular investigation. In efforts to capture C3-CAM phenotypic variation we set up a watered, droughted, re-watered experiment. Such an experimental design enabled us to detect C3-CAM intermediates; species that only express CAM under drought stress, reverting back to C3 with re-watering. Over the course of this experiment we measured AM/PM titratable acidity (a tool detecting presence/ absence of CAM activity) of leaf tissue, stomatal conductance, and collected leaf material for subsequent RNA extraction, sequencing, and comparative gene expression analyses.

RNA was successfully extracted from all leaf samples. cDNA Library preparation – a step required for next-generation sequencing – was more complicated than expected due to the presence of secondary compounds (e.g., glycerols related to succulence of the leaf tissue). After much trial, libraries were successfully made for all but 16 of the 120 leaf samples. Library sequencing was completed on August 14, 2017. The sequence data is currently being processed using Agalma, a pipeline for transcriptome assembly, phylogenetic analysis and expression analysis. Once the assembly is complete, we will use a comparative transcriptomic approach to answer the following questions: 1) how does differential gene expression of key CAM genes vary across the intermediate phenotypes, 2) which gene copies are being recruited into new CAM function, 3) are there parallel nucleotide/ amino acid changes in gene copies recruited to perform CAM, and 4) how can transcriptome data help us to better differentiate and define these C3-CAM intermediates? Such data, in conjunction with our previous phylogenetic, physiological, biochemical, and anatomical work, will allow us to begin to tease apart the evolutionary assembly of CAM.

In addition to the scientific objectives, this project included an outreach component with a local middle school. The outreach goal was to introduce 7thand 8th grade middle school students to plant biology through planting, growing, and harvesting food. With my collaborator Jillian Schneider, a middle school science teacher in Rhode Island, we built table-top greenhouses in her classroom. From seed, we grew 20 different species of plants (e.g., lettuce, kale, arugula) in the classroom. The planting, growing, transplanting, and harvesting of these plants were incorporated into her science curriculum for the year. In addition, we worked with a local restaurant to help teach the students more about the farm-to-table process.
